revised_title: Asymmetry in Testes Size and Secondary Sexual Characters in Birds
tldr: The author's study on two bird species, the barn swallow and the house sparrow, found that testes size demonstrated directional asymmetry, with the left testis being larger than the right testis. The amount of directional asymmetry was positively related to the expression of secondary sexual characters, suggesting that males with the largest degree of asymmetry had a selective advantage due to higher mating success. This relation was not confounded by variables such as body mass, body size, and age.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Evolutionary Biology
